He is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Wayne State University, where he serves as the Director of the Real-Time Systems Group and the WSU site co-Director of the NSF IUCRC eCAT center. Additionally, he is a co-Director of the the CAR Lab, collaborating with a team of talented students and utilizing state-of-the-art facilities to advance research in autonomous driving systems. He hold a Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Texas at Dallas, a Master's degree in Computer Software Engineering from the University of Science and Technology of China, and a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science from Wuhan University. His research focuses on the Integrated Hardware-Software Co-Design for Safety-Critical Cyber-Physical Systems, emphasizing the assurance of timing predictability in autonomous driving technologies. His expertise in real-time & embedded systems also drives his interest in developing computer systems that incorporate timing-critical components. This extends to projects like real-time EV fleet charging recommendation systems and the implementation of edge-enabled smart infrastructures in smart cities. He is looking for Ph.D. students in the areas of real-time embedded systems, mobile edge computing and autonomous driving. Students with either CS or CE majors are welcome to apply. For current WSU students who are interested in working with him, please stop by his office and see if there is a good match.
